content.description: Start sitting with left hand on the arete, and right hand on a side pull at a similar height to your left hand. Compress your way off the ground and find a sequence to get to the arete. Follow the crimps to the top.
content.protection: Probably good to bring a good amount of pads, as the landing is not the best.
content.location: The left arete on the boulder behind "Finger Buckets".

content.description: This freestanding boulder is a hidden gem. Start both hands in the crack at the bottom of the boulder. Move directly up the face and top out around the middle section. Great holds and many moves.
content.location: An easy way to reach this boulder is to take the hiking trail that runs along the top of the creek. This way may be difficult to find due to the boulder not being seen from the trail. Another way to reach this boulder would be to directly walk along the creek. Once you reach a large egg-shaped boulder on the creek walk directly up the hill.

content.description: Stewart Creek has many types of boulders ranging from highballs, cracks, slabs, etc. The creek lies within a steep river valley that offers beautiful scenery and seclusion. With the area being undeveloped/cleaned it's a playground for FA's.
